text: Hey guys, Emily here.
Today I am here at the Museum of Yebisu Beer.
We are going to go and find out about beer and have a tour of the factory.
So lets go.
The Yebisu Beer Museum is open from 11:00am to 19:00pm Tuesday through Sunday.
Entry is free of charge,
however if you would like to take a 40 minute history and tasting tour
it costs 500 Yen for an adult.
Which I think is very affordable.
Once you have paid for the tour you are given a badge to indicate that you will be taking the tour
and it also gives you access to the private waiting lounge area.
The fist part of the tour was about the history of Ebisu.
It was conducted in Japanese so they also gave me this English guide
so that I could follow along if I didn't understand anything.
We learnt about many things on the tour, such as,
how beer became popular in Japan,
how Yebisu Beer was established,
how it maintained it's popularity,
and how Ebisu station was named after Yebisu Beer.
We also learnt about how Yebisu beer disappeared for a time,
and how it made a comeback,
and how Yebisu beer is doing today.
They even had a little music box, which you could turn to hear the melody of the Yebisu Beer song.
After the History part of the tour was complete、
we were taken to the stage area where we could taste two glasses of Yebisu’s most popular beer.
The first was the Premium Ebisu All Malt Beer
that is a clear, golden colour.
The beer had a distinct malt taste but wasn’t too bitter.
It was very creamy and smooth.
The second was the Yebisu Kohaku Beer
which is an amber color.
It is made with roasted crystal malt.
The beer has a very distinct taste and is a lot stronger in terms of flavor than the Premium Ebisu Beer.
We were also lucky enough to try some of the traditional snacks called endou mame.
We were also taught some techniques for delicious drinking as well.
They suggested that you don’t chill the glass before drinking and just chill the beer.
They also gave one lucky person on the tour the chance to try their new Premium Royal Selection Beer before it’s release date.
They also have a museum shop which sells a variety of different Yebisu themed products,
as well as a lot of useful things that you can use in your everyday life.
I really enjoyed this tour
so if you’re ever in Ebisu and you like beer
I definitely recommend that you check it out.
If your still keen to hang around after the tour
the surrounding gardens, shops and restaurants are quite nice as well.
So we just finished the beer tour and it was so good,
we had two different beers, one was really strong and one was good.
but yeah, i really enjoyed Yebisu Beer.
I think i have been converted.
I used to like Asahi and that was all i drank but now Yebisu is quite nice.
